raw_text:
UK set to cut back on embassies
 
 Nine overseas embassies and high commissions will close in an effort to save money, UK Foreign Secretary Jack Straw has announced.
 
 The Bahamas, East Timor, Madagascar and Swaziland are among the areas affected by the biggest shake-up for the diplomatic service for years. Other diplomatic posts are being turned over to local staff. Mr Straw said the move would save £6m a year to free up cash for priorities such as fighting terrorism.
 
 Honorary consuls will be appointed in some of the areas affected by the embassy closures. Nine consulates or consulates general will also be closed, mostly in Europe and America.
 
 They include Dallas in the US, Bordeaux in France and Oporto in Portugal, with local staff replacing UK representation in another 11. The changes are due to be put in place before the end of 2006, with most savings made from cutting staff and running costs. Some of the money will have to be used to fund redundancy payments. In a written statement, Mr Straw said: "The savings made will help to underpin higher priority work in line with the Foreign and Commonwealth Office's strategic priorities, including counter- proliferation, counter-terrorism, energy and climate change. "Some of the savings will also be redeployed to strategic priority work within certain regions where we are closing posts. "In Africa, for instance, we plan to create new jobs to cover these issues across the region, with a new post in Nairobi to help support our work on climate change, one in Nigeria to cover energy and one in Pretoria to cover regional issues more generally as well as covering Maseru and Mbabane."
 
 The Foreign Office currently has about 6,100 UK-based staff. It has opened major new missions on Baghdad and Basra in Iraq, Kabul in Afghanistan and Pyongyang in North Korea since 1997 in response to what the government says are changing needs. Since 1997 10 overseas posts have been closed - excluding Wednesday's cuts - but 18 new embassies or consulates have been opened. The shake-up is aimed at helping making £86m in efficiency savings between 2005 and 2008. The chancellor has demanded all government departments make similar savings. Shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancram said there was a constant need to ensure value for money from foreign missions. "But the government must give a far clearer reason for making the dramatic changes it has announced and must show that British commercial interests and the interests of Britons abroad will not be adversely affected," he said.
llama3.2:1b: The UK is closing 9 overseas embassies and high commissions, with 11 more expected to close in 2006, due to budget cuts and a desire for efficiency savings.
The closures affect the Bahamas, East Timor, Madagascar, Swaziland, and some African countries.
The changes will be implemented before the end of 2006 and will result in £6m annual cost savings.
Some of this money will be used to fund redundancy payments.
The UK Foreign Office currently has about 6,100 staff and has opened new missions in several countries since 1997.
llama3.2:3b: The UK is set to close nine overseas embassies and high commissions, with some posts being turned over to local staff, to save £6m a year.
Nine consulates or consulates general will also be closed, mostly in Europe and America.
Honorary consuls will be appointed in affected areas.
The move aims to free up cash for priorities such as fighting terrorism and energy climate change.
gemma2:2b: The UK Foreign Office is closing nine embassies and high commissions, along with nine consulates, to save money and prioritize spending on counter-terrorism, climate change, and energy.
These closures will affect areas like the Bahamas, East Timor, Madagascar, and Swaziland, while honorary consuls will be appointed in affected regions.
The savings are expected to amount to £6 million annually.
The changes aim to achieve overall efficiency savings of £86 million between 2005 and 2008.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UK embassies and consulates are set to close, saving £6m annually.
Nine overseas embassies and high commissions are being cut back while other diplomatic posts are overhauled with some areas closing down.
Consulars will also be appointed in some of the affected areas.
The Foreign Office currently has about 6,100 UK-based staff.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The UK plans to close nine overseas embassies, save £6 million annually, and redirect funds towards counter-terrorism and environmental priorities, aiming to reduce costs by 86 million pounds over five years while maintaining strategic presence in key regions like Africa, Asia, and the Middle East.
qwen2.5:3b: UK set to cut back on nine embassies and high commissions in effort to save money, with savings aimed at priorities like terrorism.
Honorary consuls may replace UK representation in some areas; 9 other consulates will close.
The move aims to free up cash for strategic priorities such as counter-terrorism and climate change.
Overseas posts were closed or opened since 1997 in response to changing needs.
Shadow foreign secretary criticizes the changes, questioning their necessity and impact on British interests abroad.
opencoder:1.5b:
UK set to cut back on embassies

The announcement by Jack Straw on Friday, marking the end of diplomatic post closures, highlighted how the country's economic growth was underpinned by a decline in diplomatic service.
The move aimed at saving money and expanding efficiency by closing more than nine overseas embassies is an attempt to reduce the cost of international travel and communications.

The announcement also underscores the importance of the Foreign Office's increased investment in strategic priority work, which includes counter-propaganda campaigns against global terrorism, energy and climate change, and other related issues.
Meanwhile, a vast number of new government jobs were created as a result of these changes.
Overall, the strategy was to reduce unnecessary travel and communications, streamline operations, and strengthen international relations, all while ensuring financial stability for future growth.
smollm:1.7b: The UK set to cut back on embassies, Bahamas, East Timor, Madagascar, Swaziland, Honorary consuls will be appointed in some areas, 9 embassies or consulates will close, mostly in Europe and America, Savings made from cutting staff and running costs.

Some of the savings will be redeployed to strategic priorities within certain regions where UK representation is closing posts, new jobs created to cover these issues across Africa, new missions opened on Baghdad and Basra in Iraq, Kabul in Afghanistan and Pyongyang in North Korea since 1997 in response to changing needs.
Since 1997 18 new embassies or consulates have been opened - excluding Wednesday's cuts - but 18 new embassies or consulates have been opened.
The chancellor has demanded all government departments make similar savings and must show that British commercial interests and the interests of Britons abroad will not be adversely affected.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The UK government plans to reduce embassies starting from September 2006, with closures in key areas including the Bahamas, East Timor, Madagascar, and Swaziland.
Nine overseas embassies will be closed, along with local staff taking over UK representatives in other posts.
This move aims to save £6 million annually, free up funds for priorities such as combating terrorism.
The changes are set to occur before 2006, with savings from staff reductions and operational costs.
Key closures include Dallas in the US, Bordeaux in France, Oporto in Portugal, and local staff replacing UK representation in 11 other posts.
Strategic priorities will be supported through the £86 million efficiency savings between 2005 and 2008.
The foreign office currently has approximately 6,100 UK-based staff, having opened major missions on Baghdad, Basra, Kabul, and Pyongyang since 1997.

Since 1997, 10 overseas posts have been closed (excluding the cuts on Wednesday), but 18 new embassies or consulates have been opened, aiming to reduce £86 million in efficiency savings over three years.
The government emphasizes ensuring value for money from missions and highlighting a clear reason for changes while safeguarding British commercial interests abroad.
tinyllama:1.1b: The UK Foreign Office has announced plans to cut back on embassies, high commissions, consulates, and consulate general in an effort to save £6m annually while also strengthening strategic priority work in specific regions, including counter-prolife terrorism, energy, climate change, and counter-terrorism.

The closures and new missions will impact nine overseas embassies, high commission, consulates, and general posts, affecting diplomatic staff in the Bahamas, East Timor, Madagascar, Swaziland, Dallas, Bordeaux, Oporto (Portugal), Dallas, and Oporto.

The cuts will save £6m annually but will impact the Department for Foreign Affairs and Trade's ability to deliver strategic priority work in Africa, including new jobs to cover climate change, regional energy issues, and general posts in North Korea, Afghanistan, and Iraq, and Pyongyang.
The government has demanded that all government departments make similar efficiency saving cuts by 2008.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The UK government has decided to close down nine overseas embassies and high commissions in an effort to save £6 million per year, as part of a broader strategy to free up cash for other priorities.
This decision is aimed at ending the practice of allocating British staff to non-essential posts abroad, according to Jack Straw, the UK Foreign Secretary.
The closures affect embassies and high commissions in the Bahamas, East Timor, Madagascar, Swaziland, and several African countries.
This change is part of a larger effort to increase Britain's global presence and capabilities in the face of changing priorities.
The Bahamas is affected by the most significant closures, with nine embassies and high commissions being closed, while other posts have been turned over to local staff.
The UK has decided to appoint honorary consuls in some areas where British representation is needed, such as in Europe and America.
In addition, an additional 10 consulates will be closed, mostly in the European and American regions.
Some of these closures are expected to take place before the end of the year, while others have been pushed back until the middle of next year.
The changes being made are part of a broader strategy to save £6 million per year from the current level of spending on foreign missions.
This decision is in line with the UK government's strategic priorities and its commitment to underpin high priority work with cutting staff and running costs.

The overseas embassies and high commissions affected by these closures will be closed until the end of 2006, and some of the savings made from cutting staff and running costs will have to be used to fund redundancy payments for local staff.

In Africa, there are plans to create new jobs in areas where British representation is needed, while in certain regions where there is no need for British staff, new posts may be created to cover these issues more generally as well as covering Maseru and Mbabane.
phi:2.7b: UK Foreign Secretary Jack Straw announces cuts in overseas embassies and high commissions, with nine to close and others turned over to local staff.
The move is aimed at saving money for priorities such as fighting terrorism and is expected to save £6m a year.
Some of the savings will be used to fund redundancy payments.
orca-mini:3b: The UK is set to reduce its diplomatic presence by closing nine embassies and high commissions and reducing the number of consuls general in other countries.
These changes are expected to save around £6m a year, with some of the money redeployed to higher priority areas such as counter-proliferation, counter-terrorism, energy and climate change.
The closures include posts in Dallas, Bordeaux, Oporto, and several others in Europe and North America.
In addition, nine consulates or consulates general are being closed, with local staff replacing UK representation in another 11 countries.
The changes are aimed at making efficiency savings of £86m between 2005 and 2008.
hermes3:3b: UK plans to close 9 overseas embassies & save ~$6m/year by cutting staff & costs, freeing up funds for high-priority tasks like counter-terrorism and energy/climate change.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The UK is closing nine embassies and high commissions to save £6m a year, which will be redirected towards priorities like fighting terrorism.
Nine consulates or consulates general will also close, replacing UK staff with local representatives.
The changes are set to take place by the end of 2006, some of the funding will go toward redundancy payments.
This reorganization aims to make £86m in efficiency savings between 2005 and 2008, as demanded by the chancellor.
stablelm2:1.6b:
UK plans to close nine overseas embassies and high commissions, affecting diplomatic posts in areas such..
Steps:
1.
2 Focusing on key ideas and details.

Identify important points: 
   - Closure of 9 embassies including Bahamas, East Timor, Madagascar, Swaziland, etc.,
   - Dallas (US), Bordeaux (France) & Oporto (Portugal) among closed consulates/consulates general
   - Embassy closures mainly in Europe and America
   - Most savings will be made from cutting staff and running costs
   - Honorary consuls will be appointed or some posts turned over to local staff
   - Closure of nine consulates or consulates general mostly in Europe and America (including Dallas, Bordeaux, and Oporto)
   
4.
Create a summary based on the key points, preserving important details and ideas.

Summary: UK plans to close nine overseas embassies as part of efforts to save £6m annually for counter-terrorism and other priorities, mainly due to budget constraints in response to government demands.
Diplomatic posts will be turned over to local staff and some will have honorary consuls appointed or replaced by local staff.
Most savings made will help underpin higher priority work in line with the Foreign and Commonwealth Office's strategic priorities.
granite3.1-dense:2b: UK Foreign Secretary Jack Straw has announced plans to close nine embassies and high commissions, primarily affecting The Bahamas, East Timor, Madagascar, and Swaziland.
This move aims to save £6 million annually for other government priorities, such as counter-terrorism and climate change initiatives.
Local staff will replace UK representatives in these areas, along with nine consulates or consulates general, including Dallas (US), Bordeaux (France), and Oporto (Portugal).
The changes are expected to be implemented by the end of 2006, primarily through reducing staff and operational costs.
Some savings will also fund redundancy payments for affected employees.
The Foreign Office, currently employing about 6,100 UK-based staff, has recently expanded its presence in regions like Iraq, Afghanistan, and North Korea.
Since 1997, it has closed 10 overseas posts while opening new missions in Baghdad, Kabul, and Pyongyang.
The shake-up is part of an overall £86 million efficiency push for government departments by 2008, with the chancellor demanding similar savings across all sectors.

Shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancram criticized the announcement, emphasizing the need for a more compelling justification from the government to ensure British commercial interests and the welfare of Britons abroad remain unaffected by these cuts.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The UK will close nine overseas embassies and high commissions, including those in the Bahamas, East Timor, Madagascar, and Swaziland, to save £6 million annually.
Some diplomatic posts will be handed over to local staff, and honorary consuls will be appointed in affected areas.
Nine consulates, including those in Dallas, Bordeaux, and Oporto, will also close.
The savings will be redirected to priorities such as counter-terrorism, energy, and climate change, with new positions created in Africa.
The Foreign Office, which has about 6,100 UK-based staff, has opened new missions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and North Korea since 1997 while closing 10 posts and opening 18 new ones.
The changes are part of a broader effort to achieve £86 million in efficiency savings by 2008.
Shadow Foreign Secretary Michael Ancram called for clearer justification to ensure British interests are not harmed.
